original_data.question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with increasing swelling of his right jaw for the past 2 months. She notes that he has been treated several times with different antibiotics, but that they have not helped. She reports no recent history of fever, chills, or night sweats. The boy has no significant medical history. He emigrated to the United States with his family from Nigeria 1 month ago. He is in the 85th percentile for height and weight, and he has been meeting all developmental milestones. His temperature is 37.8℃ (100.0℉). On physical examination, the patient has a prominent 8 × 8 cm mass over the right mandible. The mass has partially distorted the borders of the mandible and cheek. The overlying skin is erythematous. The mass is firm, immobile, and tender. The contralateral side of the face shows no abnormalities. An oral examination shows the disruption of the ipsilateral lower teeth and oral mucosa. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A biopsy of the mass is performed and a histopathologic analysis is seen in the image. Which of the following microorganisms is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?

model_response:
The image shows a lymph node with numerous small abscesses surrounded by epithelioid macrophages. This is consistent with a diagnosis of cat-scratch disease, which is caused by Bartonella henselae. The history of a cat scratch and the characteristic clinical and histologic findings make the diagnosis straightforward. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause lymphadenopathy, but the characteristic finding is a large cell containing an owl’s eye appearance. Epstein barr virus (EBV) can cause lymphadenopathy, but the characteristic finding is a large cell containing an owl’s eye appearance. Yersinia pestis can cause lymphadenopathy, but the characteristic finding is a large cell containing an owl’s eye appearance.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Those facilities which administer health services to individuals who do not require hospitalization or institutionalization.
Female parents, human or animal.
Abnormal fluid accumulation in TISSUES or body cavities. Most cases of edema are present under the SKIN in SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Subject to a process with the aim of readying for some purpose, improving, or remedying a condition.

Substances naturally produced by microorganisms or their derivatives that selectively target microorganisms not humans. Antibiotics kill or inhibit the growth of microorganisms by targeting components of the microbial cell absent from human cells, including bacterial cell walls, cell membrane, and 30S or 50S ribosomal subunits. These substances are used in the treatment of bacterial and other microbial infections.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
The sudden sensation of being cold. It may be accompanied by SHIVERING.
Perspiration experienced nocturnally that is unrelated to environmental temperature.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
A country in NORTH AMERICA between CANADA and MEXICO.
A social group consisting of parents or parent substitutes and children.
A republic in western Africa, south of NIGER between BENIN and CAMEROON. Its capital is Abuja.
Every month.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
An important event in the progress, development, or history of something or in someone's life.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
A boundary line or the area immediately inside the boundary.
The largest and strongest bone of the FACE constituting the lower jaw. It supports the lower teeth.
The part of the face that is below the eye and to the side of the nose and mouth.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
A response indicating that an individual is not mobile.
Applied to pain that is tender, i.e., elicited by touching the affected body part. []
On or relating to the opposite side of the body.
A line segment forming part of the perimeter of a plane figure.
The anterior portion of the head that includes the skin, muscles, and structures of the forehead, eyes, nose, mouth, cheeks, and jaw.
A systematic evaluation of the tissues and structures in the mouth.
An interruption or interference in continuity.
Having to do with the same side of the body.

A malocclusion of the teeth in which maxillary incisor and canine teeth project over the mandiblar teeth. The overlap is measured parallel to the occlusal plane and therefore is called horizontal overlap.

Lining of the ORAL CAVITY, including mucosa on the GUMS; the PALATE; the LIP; the CHEEK; floor of the mouth; and other structures. The mucosa is generally a nonkeratinized stratified squamous EPITHELIUM covering muscle, bone, or glands but can show varying degree of keratinization at specific locations.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Removal and pathologic examination of specimens from the living body.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Description:A characteristic representing a single file reference that contains two or more views of the same dosage form of the product; in most cases this should represent front and back views of the dosage form, but occasionally additional views might be needed in order to capture all of the important physical characteristics of the dosage form. Any imprint and/or symbol should be clearly identifiable, and the viewer should not normally need to rotate the image in order to read it. Images that are submitted with SPL should be included in the same directory as the SPL file.
A microscopic organism. The term microorganism may refer to a prokaryote or eukaryote, and may be a unicellular or multicellular organism. All taxonomic kingdoms contain microorganisms.
Joined in some kind of relationship.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
